intro: Carum podagraria, commonly known as greater celandine, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its branched, aromatic stems and compound leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in umbels, which are typical of the carrot family. Its roots are thick and fleshy, often used in traditional medicine for their purported healing properties. However, the plant contains toxic compounds and should be handled with care.
